course.title: Build Your First App with Lovable

challenges.title: Your First Prompt
challenges.description: Build working software in the first few minutes. No code, no setup, just words.

steps.title: You're about to build something real

content.body:
In the next few minutes, you'll create a working app. Not a mockup. Not a prototype. A real, functioning web app that runs in browsers on phones and computers.

You won't write any code. Instead, you'll describe what you want, and Lovable will build it.

This approach is called **vibe coding**: building software by describing it in plain language rather than writing code yourself.

steps.subtitle: No code required

content.body:
Lovable builds **web applications**, software that runs in web browsers. That means:

- Works on phones, tablets, and computers
- No app store needed, share a link and anyone can use it
- Updates instantly when you make changes

Whether you're building a tool for your book club, a simple dashboard, or a side project, it all starts with describing what you want.

Here's something that trips up beginners: vague prompts get vague results.

If you type "make me an app for my book club," Lovable will build *something*, but it might not be what you had in mind. The AI fills in the gaps with guesses.

Structured prompts give Lovable clear instructions. You'll get closer to what you want on the first try, and spend less time fixing things afterwards.

Here's a structure that works well for initial prompts:

```markdown
## Product overview
What is this app? What does it do?

## User flow
What will users do in the app? List the main steps.

## Platform requirements
- It's a mobile-first platform. Optimise layout, font sizes, and buttons for mobile. Prioritise speed and readability.
- The platform is accessible. Implement WCAG AA compliance.

## Design system
- Brand colours
- Heading font
- Paragraph font
- Logo (optional)

## Target user
Who is this for? What problem does it solve for them?
```

Don't worry about getting every section perfect. You can always refine later. The goal is to give Lovable enough context to build something useful.

Here's how this looks for a Book Club Organiser app:

```markdown
## Product overview
A simple web app for book clubs to suggest, vote on, and choose their next book.

## User flow
1. Create a book club with a name
2. Share an invite link with members
3. Members suggest books (title and author)
4. Everyone votes on suggestions
5. The most-voted book is highlighted as the winner

## Platform requirements
- Mobile-first design. Optimise layout, font sizes, and buttons for mobile.
- Accessible. Implement WCAG AA compliance.

## Design system
- Primary colour: #06BEAC (teal)
- Font: Inter

## Target user
Book club organisers who are tired of scattered WhatsApp messages and endless debates about what to read next.
```

This gives Lovable a clear picture of what to build.

Open [Lovable](https://lovable.dev) in a new tab. If you don't have an account, create one (it's free to start).

You have two options:

**Option A:** Copy the Book Club Organiser prompt from the previous step and paste it into Lovable.

**Option B:** Write your own prompt using the formula. Think of something you'd find useful: a simple tool, a personal project, anything that excites you.

Either way, paste your prompt and press Enter.

Then watch. Lovable will start building your app in real time.

content.description: You've just built your first app. Take a moment to explore what Lovable created. Click around, try the features. Then write down one thing that surprised you or worked better than expected.
content.subDescription: Noticing what works well (and what doesn't) will help you give better instructions in future prompts.

content.question: Why do structured prompts work better than vague requests?
options: They use special keywords Lovable recognises
They give Lovable clear context so it makes fewer guesses
They cost fewer credits
They bypass the AI entirely
content.explanation: When you provide clear context (what the app does, who it's for, how it should look), Lovable makes fewer assumptions. Fewer assumptions mean fewer surprises in the result.

content.question: What can users do with a web app built in Lovable?
options: Download it from the App Store
Access it through any web browser on phone or computer
Run it only on Windows computers
Use it only when connected to Lovable's servers
content.explanation: Web apps run in browsers, so they work on any device with a browser. No app store downloads required, just share a link.

steps.title: You just built your first app!

content.description: You went from nothing to a working web app using plain language.
content.subDescription: This is the core skill of vibe coding. You describe, Lovable builds. The rest of this course will help you refine that skill, navigate Lovable's tools, and turn your rough first draft into something polished.
content.nextModule: **Next:** Learn to iterate in small steps, the approach that saves credits and keeps you in control.

challenges.title: Iterate and Improve
challenges.description: Build in small steps, test after each one, and stay in control of what Lovable creates.

content.body:
You have a working app. Now what?

Here's something beginners often do: they write a massive prompt asking for five new features at once. Then something breaks, and they can't tell which change caused the problem.

A better approach: **one feature at a time**. Make a small change, test it, confirm it works, then move on.

This isn't slower. It's actually faster because you spend less time debugging mystery bugs.

Lovable uses credits for each prompt you send. Credits are based on complexity, not word count.

Here's what might surprise you: detailed, specific prompts often use fewer credits overall than vague ones. Why? Because vague prompts lead to back-and-forth fixes, each of which costs credits.

Being clear upfront saves resources.

steps.title: Lovable builds more than you ask for

content.body:
When you describe a feature, Lovable often adds related functionality you didn't explicitly request. Sometimes this is helpful. Sometimes it's not what you wanted.

Working in small steps helps you stay in control. You'll notice when Lovable adds something unexpected, and you can address it before building more on top.

If something appears that you don't want, you can simply say: "Remove the notification feature you just added" in your next prompt.

steps.subtitle: Expect some extras

content.body:
Here's a liberating truth: **it's cheap to start over**.

If your app becomes tangled with features you don't want, or if you've gone down the wrong path, you can create a new project and rebuild from scratch. With a good prompt, you can recreate the core of your app in minutes.

This mindset frees you to experiment. Try that risky feature. If it doesn't work, you have options.

steps.title: When to tweak vs when to start fresh

content.body:
**Tweak** when:
- You want to adjust something small (colours, text, layout)
- The core of your app is solid
- You can clearly describe what needs to change

**Start fresh** when:
- You've made many conflicting changes
- The app feels tangled and unpredictable
- You've learned so much that your original prompt feels outdated

There's no shame in starting over. Professional developers do it constantly. Sometimes the fastest path forward is a clean slate with better instructions.

steps.subtitle: Choose your path

content.body:
Go back to your app in Lovable. Think of one small feature to add.

For the Book Club Organiser, this might be:
- "Add a vote counter next to each book that shows the current number of votes"
- "Show the book with the most votes at the top of the list"

For your own app, pick something similarly focused. One feature. One prompt.

Send it, then test. Does it work? Did Lovable add anything unexpected?

content.question: Why is building one feature at a time recommended?
options: It's required by Lovable's terms of service
It helps you identify which change caused problems if something breaks
It uses more credits, which supports Lovable
It makes the app load faster
content.explanation: When you build incrementally, any bug must have come from your most recent change. This makes problems much easier to track down and fix.

content.question: When might starting a new project be faster than fixing an existing one?
options: When you need to change a button colour
When Lovable suggests it
When your app has become tangled with conflicting changes
Never, you should always persist with your current project
content.explanation: Sometimes projects accumulate changes that conflict with each other. Starting fresh with a clearer prompt can be faster than untangling the mess, especially now that you understand the feature better.

content.description: You understand how to add features one at a time and when to start fresh.
content.subDescription: This discipline will save you hours of frustration. Small steps keep you in control and make problems easy to spot.
content.nextModule: **Next:** Master Lovable's interface so you can preview, edit, and refine your app with confidence.

challenges.title: Navigate the Lovable Interface
challenges.description: Find your way around Lovable without getting lost.

content.body:
Lovable's interface has several parts. Understanding where things live will help you work faster.

On the left, you'll see your chat history with Lovable. In the centre, there's a preview of your app. And you have various tools for inspecting, editing, and managing your project.

Let's explore the features you'll use most often.

The preview shows your app running live. You can interact with it, click buttons, fill forms, and see how everything behaves.

**To test on mobile:** Click the mobile icon in the preview toolbar to see how your app looks on a phone-sized screen. This is important because many users will access your app on their phones.

**To open full-screen:** Click the external link icon to open your app in a new browser tab. This gives you a better sense of how real users will experience it.

You can view the code Lovable generates by clicking on the code icon. You don't need to understand it, but it's there if you're curious.

As you learn more about web development (there's a separate course for that), this view becomes more useful. You might spot something that looks off, or understand why a certain feature behaves a certain way.

For now, know it exists. You can safely ignore it.

Here's a powerful feature: **Visual edits** lets you click on elements in your app and change them directly.

Click the Visual edits button at the bottom of your screen. Then click on any text, button, or element in your preview. A panel appears where you can modify colours, spacing, text content, and more.

This is perfect for quick tweaks without writing a prompt. Changed your mind about a heading? Click it and type something new.

To add images, logos, or other files to your app, you can either:

1. **Mention them in your prompt:** "Add a logo in the header" and attach the image file to your message
2. **Upload directly:** Drag and drop files into the chat

Lovable stores your assets and includes them in your app. If you later want to change an image, you can upload a new one and ask Lovable to swap it.

Want to change the overall look quickly? You can ask Lovable to apply different design approaches:

- "Make the design more minimal"
- "Use a dark colour scheme"
- "Make it feel more playful with rounded corners and brighter colours"

These broad prompts can transform the vibe of your app without changing its functionality.

Open your app in Lovable. Click the **Visual edits** button.

Now make three changes:
1. Change a heading or piece of text
2. Adjust a colour somewhere
3. Modify the spacing or size of an element

Notice how direct this feels. For small tweaks, Visual edits is often faster than writing a prompt.

content.question: Why should you test your app in mobile view?
options: Mobile view uses fewer credits
Many users will access your app on phones
It runs faster in mobile view
Lovable requires mobile testing before publishing
content.explanation: A significant portion of users browse on their phones. Testing in mobile view helps you catch layout problems and ensure buttons are easy to tap.

content.question: What is Visual edits best suited for?
options: Building entirely new features
Quick tweaks to text, colours, and spacing
Debugging complex logic problems
Managing your Lovable subscription
content.explanation: Visual edits excels at direct manipulation, clicking on something and changing it. For larger features or logic changes, prompts work better.

content.description: You can preview your app, make visual edits, and manage assets.
content.subDescription: These tools let you refine your app quickly. Visual edits for small tweaks, prompts for bigger changes.
content.nextModule: **Next:** Learn to experiment safely using bookmarks and reverts, so you never lose good work.

challenges.title: Experiment and Undo Mistakes
challenges.description: Be prepared when something breaks. Learn to save good versions and roll back bad changes.

content.body:
Every change you make in Lovable is automatically saved. Your entire history is preserved.

This means you can experiment freely. Try that risky feature. If it breaks something, you can go back to a working version.

But with a long history, finding "the version where everything worked" can be tricky. That's where bookmarks come in.

steps.title: Bookmarking stable versions

content.body:
A **bookmark** marks a specific point in your project's history. Think of it as planting a flag that says "this version works."

**When to bookmark:**
- After adding a feature that works correctly
- Before trying something risky or experimental
- Whenever you have a version you'd hate to lose

To create a bookmark, click the bookmark icon next to any message in your chat history.

steps.subtitle: Plant a flag on working versions

content.body:
If something goes wrong, you can **revert** to any previous version.

Find the message in your history where things were working. Click the revert option. Lovable will restore your project to that exact state.

Anything built after that point will be undone, but your chat history remains visible. You can still read what you tried, even though the code has been rolled back.

steps.title: When to revert vs when to fix

content.body:
**Revert** when:
- Multiple things broke and you're not sure why
- The last several changes made things progressively worse
- You want a clean slate to try a different approach

**Fix forward** when:
- You understand what's wrong
- The issue is isolated and small
- The recent changes are mostly good with one problem

There's no wrong answer. If you're spending more than a few minutes trying to fix something, reverting might be faster.

steps.subtitle: Choose your strategy

content.body:
Let's practise this workflow:

1. Open your app in Lovable
2. **Bookmark** the current version (find the bookmark icon in your recent chat)
3. Try something experimental. Ask Lovable to add a feature you're unsure about, or make a significant design change
4. Test it. Does it work? Do you like it?
5. If not, **revert** to your bookmarked version

This is how you experiment safely. Bookmark the good, try the new, revert if needed.

content.question: When is the best time to create a bookmark?
options: Only when Lovable prompts you to
After confirming a feature works correctly
At the start of every session
When you're about to delete your project
content.explanation: Bookmarking after a successful change creates a known-good checkpoint. If future changes cause problems, you have a reliable point to return to.

content.question: What happens to your chat history when you revert?
options: It's completely deleted
It remains visible, but the code is rolled back
It's hidden until you pay for premium
It's exported as a PDF
content.explanation: Reverting changes the code back to an earlier state, but your conversation history stays intact. You can still see what you tried and learn from it.

content.description: You know how to bookmark stable versions and revert when things go wrong.
content.subDescription: This safety net means you can be bold. Try new ideas knowing you can always go back. Professional developers use version control the same way.
content.nextModule: **Next:** Unlock more powerful features like planning mode, knowledge files, and integrations.

challenges.title: Go Beyond the Interface
challenges.description: Make your app more sophisticated with planning mode, knowledge files, and backend features.

content.body:
You've got the fundamentals. Now let's explore features that help you build more complex apps.

These tools aren't required for simple projects, but they become valuable as your ideas grow. Think of them as power-ups you can reach for when needed.

**Planning mode** lets Lovable think through complex features before building them.

When you turn on Plan mode (look for the toggle at the bottom of your chat), Lovable will analyse your request, break it down into steps, and show you the plan before writing any code.

This is useful for larger features where you want to see the approach first. You can give feedback on the plan before Lovable starts building.

While planning mode is helpful, don't over-plan. Lovable works best when you build as you go.

Here's why: as your app grows, earlier context can become stale. This is called **context rot**. A plan made at the start might not account for everything you've learned along the way.

Use planning mode for complex features, but keep plans focused. Build, test, then plan the next step.

**Knowledge files** give Lovable persistent context it can reference across prompts.

You might add:
- A description of your brand voice
- Details about your user personas
- Technical constraints or preferences
- Common terms specific to your domain

Lovable will reference these files when relevant, so you don't have to repeat context in every prompt.

steps.title: API keys and the Secrets panel

content.body:
When your app needs to connect to external services (payment processing, email sending, AI features), you'll need **API keys**.

API keys are like passwords that let your app talk to other services. **Never put API keys in your prompts.** They could end up visible in your code.

Instead, use Lovable's **Secrets** panel. This is a secure place to store API keys. When you ask Lovable to integrate a service, it will prompt you to add the key through this panel.

steps.subtitle: Keep secrets secret

content.body:
**Lovable Cloud** provides backend features without requiring you to set up servers.

Need your app to:
- Save data to a database?
- Authenticate users with login/signup?
- Run code on a server?

Lovable Cloud handles this. Just describe what you need ("let users save their favourite books") and Lovable sets up the backend infrastructure.

When you add backend features, Lovable might show security warnings. Don't panic.

These warnings mean Lovable has detected something that needs attention, often related to who can access what data. Common examples:
- "This data might be accessible to anyone"
- "Consider adding authentication"
- "Row-level security recommended"

Read the warning, understand what it's suggesting, and follow the recommended fix. Lovable usually provides a button or prompt to address it.

Let's try planning mode:

1. Turn on **Plan** mode in Lovable (toggle at the bottom)
2. Ask Lovable to add a moderately complex feature. For the Book Club Organiser, try: "Add a feature where the club organiser can set a deadline for voting, and the app automatically announces the winner when the deadline passes"
3. Review the plan Lovable creates
4. Give feedback if needed, or approve and let it build

Notice how you can shape the approach before any code is written.

content.question: Where should you store API keys in Lovable?
options: In your prompt, so Lovable knows about them
In a knowledge file
In the Secrets panel
In your app's visible code
content.explanation: The Secrets panel is designed for sensitive information like API keys. Putting keys in prompts or code could expose them publicly.

content.question: Why shouldn't you over-plan at the start of a project?
options: Planning uses too many credits
Early plans can become stale as you learn more (context rot)
Lovable doesn't support long plans
Planning mode is only for debugging
content.explanation: As your app evolves, early assumptions may no longer apply. Building incrementally lets you adjust your approach based on what you learn along the way.

content.description: You know how to use planning mode, knowledge files, API keys, and Lovable Cloud.
content.subDescription: These tools let you build more sophisticated apps. Use them when needed, but remember the basics still apply, small steps, test often, bookmark good versions.
content.nextModule: **Next:** Publish your app and share it with the world.

challenges.title: Publish Your App
challenges.description: Put your work on the internet and share it with others.

steps.title: Time to ship

content.body:
You've built something. Now let's put it on the internet where people can actually use it.

Publishing in Lovable is straightforward. Your app gets a public URL that anyone can visit. No app stores, no complicated deployment processes.

steps.subtitle: From your computer to the world

content.body:
A few quick things to set up before going live:

**Favicon:** The small icon that appears in browser tabs. Ask Lovable: "Set the favicon to [describe or upload an image]"

**Meta tags:** Information that appears when someone shares your link on social media. Ask Lovable: "Set the page title to [your title] and the description to [your description]"

**Thumbnail:** The image that shows when your link is shared. You can upload one and ask Lovable to set it as the social sharing image.

These details make your app look polished when shared.

When you're ready, click the **Publish** button in Lovable.

Your app will be deployed to a public URL. This usually takes a few seconds.

Once published, you'll get a link like `your-app-name.lovable.app`. This is your live app. Share it with anyone.

Your published app is live, but no one will find it unless you share the link.

It won't appear in search engines right away. It's not listed in any directory. This is actually useful, you control who sees it.

Share the link directly with people you want to test it. Post it on social media if you want a wider audience. The distribution is in your hands.

Here's an important mindset shift: **ship before you're ready**.

Waiting until everything is perfect means waiting forever. Real user feedback is more valuable than your guesses about what users want.

Publish something basic. Share it with one person. Ask what they think. Then improve based on real input.

This is how successful products are built, in public, with feedback, iteratively.

Getting your app to 80% good takes about 20% of the effort.

Getting that final 20% of polish takes the remaining 80% of the effort.

This means an imperfect version shipped today is often more valuable than a perfect version shipped months from now. You can polish forever, or you can learn from real users.

Ship the 80% version. Polish based on what you learn.

Here's a truth about software: **apps are never finished**. They evolve.

What you publish today is version 1. Based on feedback and new ideas, you'll create version 2, then version 3. The app grows and changes over time.

Don't think of publishing as the end. Think of it as the beginning of a conversation with your users.

Let's do this:

1. Set your **favicon** (ask Lovable or upload an icon)
2. Set your **meta tags** (title and description)
3. Click **Publish**
4. Visit your live URL
5. Share it with one person and ask for their honest feedback

That last step is the important one. Real feedback from a real person will teach you more than any course.

content.question: Why is shipping an imperfect version often better than waiting for perfection?
options: Imperfect versions use fewer credits
Real user feedback is more valuable than guessing what users want
Lovable requires you to publish within 30 days
Perfect versions are not allowed
content.explanation: You learn more from one real user's feedback than from a hundred assumptions. Ship early, gather feedback, and improve based on reality.

content.question: What does the 80/20 reality of product development mean?
options: 80% of users will love your app, 20% will hate it
Getting to 80% good takes 20% of the effort; the final 20% takes 80%
You should only work on your app 20% of the time
80% of features should be cut
content.explanation: Polish is expensive. Getting something working and useful is relatively quick. Perfecting every detail takes much longer. Often the 80% version is good enough to ship and learn from.

content.description: You've published your first app. What's one piece of feedback you'll seek? Who will you share it with? Write down your plan.
content.placeholder: I'll share my app with... and ask them about...
content.subDescription: Having a specific person in mind makes it real. Commit to sharing it today.

steps.title: Congratulations! You shipped your first app!

content.description: You've gone from "I've never built anything" to "I just shipped my first app."
content.subDescription:
Look at what you've learned:

✓ **Structured prompts** that get you closer to what you want on the first try

✓ **Iterative building** with small steps and immediate testing

✓ **Lovable's interface** including preview, visual edits, and asset management

✓ **Safety nets** with bookmarks and reverts so you can experiment freely

✓ **Advanced features** like planning mode, knowledge files, and Lovable Cloud

✓ **Publishing** and sharing your work with real users

Most importantly, you've learned that building software is accessible. You don't need to write code. You just need to describe what you want clearly and be willing to iterate.

**What's next?** Keep building. Share your app with more people. Gather feedback. Improve. Start a new project with a bigger idea. The skills you've learned here will compound with practice.

You've got this!
content.nextModule: **Your next step:** Share your published app with one real person today. Ask them what they think. Their feedback is your guide to what to build next.

course.description: Go from "I've never built anything" to a published web app. Learn to prompt effectively, navigate Lovable's interface, and ship your first project to the internet.
